newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK's Kerry Securities confirms downsizing.
newsitem.headline: HK's Kerry Securities confirms downsizing.

text.p: Kerry Securities Ltd (KSL) on Wednesday confirmed local newspaper reports that the brokerage has decided to restructure and downsize, with an initial loss of 40 jobs in Hong Kong.
"Essentially, the KSL business will no longer be research focused or institutionally driven," Kerry said in a statement.
The company said it would re-focus its operations to emphasise the quality of transactions instead of the quantity.
Some 40 Hong Kong-based staff, including the research team, would be released initially, with further reductions possible, the company said.
Kerry also planned to close various overseas representative offices and a related overseas affiliate in London. The future of the New York affliate would be under review, it said.
Kerry said its funds management operations were being cut back.

"The funds management activities under Kerry Investment Management Ltd (KIML) are also being downsized," it said, adding that KIML would review its position in the funds management arena at a future date.
Kerry said it would continue to operate as a broker, be registered as a dealer with the Securities and Futures Commission and maintain its membership at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
Kerry is equally owned by Malaysian businessman Robert Kuok, who controls the Kuok Group, and the brokerage's former joint managing director Jeremy King.
